!Years as tallest
!Height to roof (m)
!class="unsortable"|Height to roof (ft)
!Floors
|- | [[122 Leadenhall Street|Leadenhall Building]] || 2014–present || 225 || 737 || 48 |- | [[Heron Tower]] || 2010–2014 || 202 || 663 || 46 |- | [[Tower 42]] || 1980–2010 || 183 || 600 || 47 |- | [[CityPoint]] || 1967–1980 || 122 || 400 || 35 |- | [[St Paul's Cathedral]] || 1710–1967 || 111 || 365 || n/a |- | [[St Mary-le-Bow]] || 1683–1710 || 72 || 236 || n/a |- | [[Monument to the Great Fire of London]] || 1677–1683 || 62 || 202 || n/a |- | [[Old St Paul's Cathedral]] || 1310–1677 || 150 || 493 || n/a |} == Transport == {{See also|Transport in London}} [[File:Bank station MMB 07.jpg|thumb|right|London Underground [[roundel]] (flanked by City dragons) at [[Bank–Monument station|Bank]] station.]] [[File:Orilla Norte del Támesis desde Tate Modern, Londres, Inglaterra, 2014-08-11, DD 123.JPG|thumb|right|The [[Millennium Bridge (London)|Millennium Bridge]], looking north towards St Paul's Cathedral and the City.]] === Rail === Seven of the eleven [[London Underground]] lines run through the City, serving eleven [[List of London Underground stations|stations]]. The [[Docklands Light Railway]] (DLR) has two [[List of Docklands Light Railway stations|stations]] within the City: [[Bank Underground station|Bank]] and [[Tower Gateway DLR station|Tower Gateway]]. Three longer-distance rail termini are in the City: [[Liverpool Street station|Liverpool Street]] (services primarily to Essex and East Anglia including [[Southend Airport]]), [[Fenchurch Street railway station|Fenchurch Street]] (services to East London and South Essex) and [[Cannon Street station|Cannon Street]] (services to the South). Moorgate is the terminus for suburban services from [[Hertfordshire]], and two through-routes operate mostly underground along the main axes: *''North to South:'' [[City Thameslink railway station|City Thameslink]] (north) and [[Blackfriars station|Blackfriars]] (south) are both on the [[Thameslink (route)|Thameslink line]] with trains running from [[Bedford]] to [[Brighton]], serving [[St Pancras International]] [[Eurostar]] terminus, [[London Gatwick Airport|Gatwick]] and [[London Luton Airport|Luton]] airports. *''East to West:'' [[Crossrail]] is under construction, but upon completion will serve [[Farringdon station|Farringdon]], [[Moorgate station|Moorgate]], and [[Liverpool Street station]]s. The [[Northern line]] connects to two other main railway termini, [[London Euston station|Euston]]) and ([[London Waterloo station|Waterloo]])); the latter has a direct connection to the City via the [[Waterloo and City Line]]. The City is in [[Travelcard Zone 1]]. === Road === [[File:Space taken vs numbers in City of London (transport).png|thumb|Space taken vs numbers in City of London (transport)http://democracy.cityoflondon.gov.uk/documents/s91800/Appendix+1+-+Traffic+in+the+City+2018.pdf]] The national [[A1 road (Great Britain)|A1]], [[A10 road (England)|A10]] [[A3 road|A3]], [[A4 road (England)|A4]], and [[A40 road]] routes begin in the City. The City is in the [[London congestion charge]] zone, with the small exception on the eastern boundary of the sections of the A1210/A1211 that are part of the [[Inner Ring Road, London|inner ring road]]. The following bridges, listed west to east (downstream), cross the [[River Thames]]: [[Blackfriars Bridge]], [[Blackfriars Railway Bridge]], [[Millennium Bridge (London)|Millennium Bridge]] (footbridge), [[Southwark Bridge]], [[Cannon Street Railway Bridge]] and [[London Bridge]]; [[Tower Bridge]] is not in the City. The City, like most of central London, is well [[Buses in London|served by buses]], including night buses. Two bus stations are in the City, at [[Aldgate bus station|Aldgate]] on the eastern boundary with Tower Hamlets, and at [[Liverpool Street bus station|Liverpool Street]] by the railway station. There are approximately 28 [[Barclays Cycle Hire]] docking stations in the City.[https://web.archive.org/web/20110411092139/https://web.barclayscyclehire.tfl.gov.uk/maps Barclays Cycle Hire Scheme] map of docking station locations A number of existing and proposed cycle routes criss-cross the City, as part of the [[London Cycle Network]].[http://www.londoncyclenetwork.org.uk/uploaded_files/library/documents/A0_City_v7.pdf London Cycle Network] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110902142354/http://www.londoncyclenetwork.org.uk/uploaded_files/library/documents/A0_City_v7.pdf |date=2 September 2011 }} City of London cycle map === River === One [[London River Services]] pier is on the Thames in the City, [[Blackfriars Millennium Pier]], though the [[Tower Millennium Pier]] lies adjacent to the boundary near the Tower of London. One of the [[Port of London]]'s 25 [[safeguarded wharf|safeguarded wharves]], [[Walbrook Wharf]], is adjacent to Cannon Street station, and is used by the Corporation to transfer waste via the river. Swan Lane Pier, just upstream of London Bridge, is proposed to be replaced and upgraded for regular passenger services, planned to take place in 2012–2015. Before then, Tower Pier is to be extended.{{cite web |url=http://www.lda.gov.uk/upload/pdf/River_Thames_Pier_Plan_Diagram_9_1.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110615021648/http://www.lda.gov.uk/upload/pdf/River_Thames_Pier_Plan_Diagram_9_1.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=15 June 2011 |title=River Thames Pier Plan |publisher=Lda.gov.uk |accessdate=30 October 2011 }} There is a public riverside walk along the river bank, opened in stages over recent years. The only section not running along the river is a short stretch at [[Queenhithe]]. The walk along Walbrook Wharf is closed to pedestrians when waste is being transferred onto barges. === Travel to work (by residents) === According to a survey conducted in March 2011, the methods by which employed residents 16-74 get to work varied widely: 48.4% go on foot; 19.5% via light rail, (i.e. [[London Underground|the Underground]], [[Docklands Light Railway|DLR]], etc.); 9.2% work mainly from home; 5.8% take the train; 5.6% travel by bus, minibus, or coach; and 5.3% go by bicycle; with just 3.4% commuting by car or van, as driver or passenger.{{cite web|title=2011 Census: QS701EW Method of travel to work, local authorities in England and Wales|url=http://www.ons.gov.uk/ons/rel/census/2011-census/key-statistics-and-quick-statistics-for-wards-and-output-areas-in-england-and-wales/rft-qs701ew.xls|publisher=Office for National Statistics|accessdate=23 November 2013}} Percentages are of all residents aged 16–74 including those not in employment. Respondents could only pick one mode, specified as the journey's longest part by distance. == Education == [[File:KCLMaughanLibrary2.jpg|thumb|The [[Maughan Library]], [[King's College London]], located on [[Chancery Lane]]]] The City has only one directly maintained primary school, Sir John Cass's Foundation Primary School at [[Aldgate]]{{cite web|url=http://www.sirjohncassprimary.org/|title=The homepage of Sir John Cass's Foundation Primary School|publisher=}} (ages 4 to 11). It is a Voluntary-Aided (VA) [[Church of England]] school, maintained by the Education Service of the City of London. City residents send their children to schools in neighbouring [[Local Education Authority|Local Education Authorities]], such as [[London Borough of Islington|Islington]], [[London Borough of Tower Hamlets|Tower Hamlets]], [[City of Westminster|Westminster]] and [[London Borough of Southwark|Southwark]]. The City controls three independent schools, [[City of London School]] (a boys' school) and [[City of London School for Girls]] in the City, and the [[City of London Freemen's School]] (co-educational day and boarding) in [[Ashtead]], Surrey. The City of London School for Girls has its own preparatory department for entrance at age seven. It is the principal sponsor of The [[City Academy, Hackney]], [[City of London Academy, Islington]], and [[City of London Academy, Southwark]].[http://www.cityoflondon.gov.uk/Corporation/our_services/Education/schools/schools.htm#muscat_highlighter_first_match City Schools] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060905022232/http://www.cityoflondon.gov.uk/Corporation/our_services/Education/schools/schools.htm#muscat_highlighter_first_match |date=5 September 2006 }} The City is home to the [[Cass Business School]], [[The London Institute of Banking & Finance]], the [[Guildhall School of Music and Drama]] and parts of three of the [[universities in London]]: the [[Maughan Library]] of [[King's College London]] on [[Chancery Lane]], the business school of [[London Metropolitan University]], and a campus of the [[University of Chicago Graduate School of Business]]. [[University of Law|The College of Law]] has its London campus in [[Moorgate]]. Part of [[Barts and The London School of Medicine and Dentistry]] is on the Barts hospital site at West Smithfield. === Public libraries === Libraries operated by the Corporation include three lending libraries; Barbican Library, Shoe Lane Library and Artizan Street Library and Community Centre. Membership is open to all – with one official proof of address required to join. Guildhall Library, and City Business Library are also public reference libraries, specialising in the history of London and business reference resources.{{cite web|url=http://www.cityoflondon.gov.uk/Corporation/LGNL_Services/Leisure_and_culture/Libraries/City_of_London_libraries/index.htm|title=City of London libraries|publisher=|access-date=14 January 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081218012827/http://www.cityoflondon.gov.uk/Corporation/LGNL_Services/Leisure_and_culture/Libraries/City_of_London_libraries/index.htm|archive-date=18 December 2008|dead-url=yes}} == Criticism == Author and journalist [[Nicholas Shaxson]] argued that, in return for the financial institutions based in the City raising loans and finance for the British government, the City "has extracted privileges and freedoms from rules and laws to which the rest of Britain must submit". He further claims that the assistance provided to the institutions based within it, many of which help their rich clients with offshore tax arrangements, mean that the City is "a [[tax haven]] in its own right".{{cite news|last=Shaxson|first=Nicholas|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/economy/2011/02/london-corporation-city|title=The tax haven in the heart of Britain |accessdate=13 January 2013|newspaper=New Statesman|date=24 February 2011}} The documentary [[The Spider's Web: Britain's Second Empire]] asserts the tax haven status that the City provides. == See also == {{Wikipedia books|London}} * [[City of London Corporation]] * [[City of London Corporation#Criticism|Criticism of the City of London Corporation]] * [[City of London School]] {{Portal bar|London}} == References [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LrObZ_HZZUc The (Secret) City of London, Part 1: History] – Video link * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=z1ROpIKZe-c The (Secret) City of London, Part 2: Government] – Video link {{City of London}}{{Navboxes |title=Articles related to the City of London |state=collapsed |list1= {{London}} {{London history}} {{City of London gates}} {{Livery Companies in the City revision.text:
{{infobox organization |name = DaneAge Association |image = |size = |caption = |abbreviation = |motto = |formation = 1986 |extinction = |type = |headquarters = [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]] |leader_title = Chief Executive |leader_name = Bjarne Hastrup<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aeldresagen.dk/om-os/sekretariat/sider/direktoer.aspx|title=Direktør|language=Danish|publisher=Ældre Sagen|accessdate=2013-11-11}}</ref> |website = [http://www.aeldresagen.dk/om-os/in-english/sider/default.aspx Official website] }} '''DaneAge Association''' ([[Danish language|Danish]]: Ældre Sagen) is a [[Denmark|Danish]] [[nonprofit organization|nonprofit]] membership organization that works for the protection of senior citizens' interests in the society. It was founded in 1986 and has about 650,000 members (2013).
==Organisation== DaneAge has 217 local chapters across Denmark. Some 14,000 volunteers do voluntary social work, arrange local membership activities, local advocacy, etc.<ref name=Daneage>{{cite web|url=http://www.aeldresagen.dk/om-os/in-english/sider/default.aspx|title=In English|publisher=Ældre Sagen|accessdate=2013-11-11}}</ref>
==Headquarters== The association's headquarters is located on the corner of [[Nørre Voldgade]] and [[Nørregade]] in central [[Copenhagen]]. It maintains a staff of about 100. The artist [[Bjørn Nørgaard]] has decorated the interior of the building. He has also designed a proposed glass dome which will create a new public space with views of the city centre. The plans were announced in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.magasinetkbh.dk/indhold/krystallen-n%C3%B8rgaard-%C3%A6ldre-sagen|title=Krystal på toppen af Nørreport|language=Danish|publisher=Magasinet KBH|accessdate=2013-11-11}}</ref>
==Magazine== Dane Age publishes the magazine Ældre Sagen Nu six times a year. It claims to be read by one third of all Danes aged 50+, placing it in the top three of all Danish magazines.<ref name=Daneage/>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.aeldresagen.dk/om-os/in-english/sider/default.aspx Official website]
[[Category:Political advocacy groups in Denmark]] [[Category:Organizations based in Copenhagen]] [[Category:1986 establishments in Denmark]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1986]]
{{Denmark-stub}}

page.title: Day of the Police of Belarus

revision.text:
[[File:Belarus Internal Troops emblem (Combined Military).png|thumb|Emblem of the Internal Troops.]] The '''Day of the Police of Belarus''' ([[Belarusian language|Belarusian]]:Дзень паліцыі Беларусі, Dzień palicyi Bielarusi) is a professional holiday of the [[Law enforcement in Belarus|Belarusian police]]. On March 4, 1917, [[Mikhail Frunze]] was appointed the chief of the militia of the city of Minsk.<ref>https://www.tvr.by/eng/news/obshchestvo/belarus_segodnya_otmechaet_den_militsii_04_03_2014_07_02_0059/</ref> This date is considered to be the birthday of the Belarusian police. The holiday was officially approved by the decree of the President of the Republic of Belarus, Alexander Lukashenko, on March 26, 1998.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://advokatby.com/belarus/feedso/bdewiun7r.htm|title=05.11.2002 О государственных праздниках, праздничных днях и памятных датах в Республике Беларусь|website=advokatby.com|access-date=2017-12-20}}</ref> It is usually celebrated with a parade of the internal troops in [[October Square, Minsk|October Square]] in Minsk.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.belarus.by/ru/government/events/lukashenko-primet-uchastie-v-torzhestvennyx-meroprijatijax-k-100-letiju-belorusskoj-militsii_i_0000053825.html|title=Лукашенко примет участие в торжественных мероприятиях к 100-летию белорусской милиции {{!}} Главные новости Беларуси - события, решения, высказывания {{!}} Belarus.by|website=www.belarus.by|language=ru|access-date=2017-12-20}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.abw.by/novosti/rb/195878/|title=В Минске прошел парад МВД - Новости Беларуси - ABW.BY|website=www.abw.by|access-date=2017-12-20}}</ref><ref>http://calendr.net/holiday/314</ref><ref>http://www.warmuseum.by/index.php/component/k2/item/764-дню-внутренних-войск-посвящается</ref>
== See also == * [[Ministry of Internal Affairs (Belarus)|Ministry of Internal Affairs of the Republic of Belarus]] * [[Law enforcement in Belarus]] * [[Ministry of the Interior Academy of the Republic of Belarus]] * [[Public holidays in Belarus]]
== References == <references />
[[Category:Public holidays in Belarus]] [[Category:Belarus stubs]]

{{Infobox spaceflight | name = Galaxy 18 | image = | image_caption = | mission_type = | operator = [[Intelsat]] | website = | COSPAR_ID = | SATCAT = | mission_duration = 15 years | spacecraft_bus = [[LS-1300]] | manufacturer = [[Space Systems/Loral]] | dry_mass = | launch_mass = {{convert|4642|kg|lb}} | power = | launch_date = {{start-date|May 21, 2008, 09:43:22|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = [[Zenit-3SL]] | launch_site = [[Odyssey (launch platform)|Odyssey]] | launch_contractor = [[Sea Launch]] | entered_service = | disposal_type = | deactivated = | orbit_epoch = | orbit_reference = [[Geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Geostationary orbit|Geostationary]] | orbit_periapsis = | orbit_apoapsis = | orbit_inclination = | orbit_period = | orbit_longitude = 123° West ({{Coord|0|-123|display=inline,title}}) | orbit_slot = | apsis = gee | trans_band = 24 [[IEEE]] [[C band (IEEE)|C band]]
24 [[IEEE]] [[Ku band|Ku band]] | trans_frequency = | trans_bandwidth = | trans_capacity = | trans_coverage = [[United States]], [[Canada]], [[Mexico]] | trans_TWTA = | trans_EIRP = | trans_HPBW = }} '''Galaxy 18''' is a [[Space Systems/Loral]] (SS/L) 1300-series hybrid [[communications satellite]] owned by [[Intelsat]] and located in [[geosynchronous orbit]] at 123° W [[longitude]], serving the continental [[United States]], [[Alaska]], [[Hawaii]], [[Mexico]], and [[Canada]] with 24 [[C band (IEEE)|C band]], and 24 [[Ku band|Ku band]] [[transponders]]. Galaxy 18 is intended to replace [[Galaxy 10R]] which was nearing the end of its design life.[https://web.archive.org/web/20080517182823/http://www.intelsat.com/network/satellite/scheduled-launch.asp Intelsat Satellite Launch Schedule] While this spacecraft is designed for a 15-year service life on orbit, [[Sea Launch]]’s direct insertion{{Citation needed|date=May 2008}} into equatorial orbit is expected to yield additional years of fuel life. Galaxy 18 was scheduled to be launched by [[Sea Launch]] on May 8, 2008 but was pushed to May 25{{Citation needed|date=May 2008}}. It was subsequently moved up to 21 May. The launch took place successfully at 09:43 [[GMT]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sea-launch.com/news_releases/nr_080521.html |title=Sea Launch Successfully Delivers Galaxy 18 to Orbit |publisher=Sea Launch |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080531014715/http://www.sea-launch.com/news_releases/nr_080521.html |archivedate=May 31, 2008 }} == Free-to-air television == Galaxy 18 is the home of many [[free-to-air]] television channels, including approximately three dozen US local stations operated by [[Equity Media Holdings|Equity Broadcasting]]. [[Ku band|Ku band]] [[DVB-S]] programming may be received by compliant [[FTA receiver]]s throughout [[North America]] using [[satellite dish]]es as small as one metre.[http://www.lyngsat.com/galaxy18.html Lyngsat: Galaxy 18] As of 2008, available free-to-air channels at 123°W include: * [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC TV]] ([[KATV-TV|KATV]], [[KKTU-LP|KKTU]], [[KTWO-TV|KTWO]]) * [[Daystar (TV network)|Daystar]] * [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox TV]] ([[KBTZ]], [[KLMN]], [[KMMF-TV|KMMF]], [[WMQF]]) * [[KWWF]] ([[Independent station (North America)|Ind.]] - [[Waterloo, Iowa]]) * [[Multimedios Television]] ([[KMCC]]) * [[MyNetworkTV]] ([[KFDF-CD]], [[KXNW|KPBI]], [[KARZ-TV|KWBF]], [[KWBM-TV|KWBM]], [[WGMU-LP]]) * [[Pac-12_Network|Pac-12 Networks]] * [[Retro Jams]] * RTN Radio * [[Telefutura]] ([[KAMT-LP|KAMT]], [[KUTF-TV|KUTF]]) * [[This TV]] ([[KCBU]], [[KEGS (TV)|KEGS]], [[KKYK-DT|KKYK]], [[KQDK-CD|KQDK-CA]], [[KQUP]], [[KTVC]], [[KWCE-LP|KWCE]], [[WBBZ-TV|WNGS]], [[WPXS]]) * [[Univisión]] ([[KEYU-LP|KEYU]], [[KUTH]], [[KUWF-LP|KUWF]], [[KXUN-LD|KXUN-LP]], [[WNYI]], [[WUMN-TV|WUMN]]) * [[University of Washington|University of Washington TV]] and the [[ResearchChannel]] * [[United States Department of Veterans Affairs|Veterans Affairs Knowledge Network]] Free ethnic programming includes [[Aaj TV]], [[Hum TV]], [[Peace TV]] and [[TV One (Pakistan)]]. All Equity Media-owned stations are programmed from a [[centralcasting|central hub]] in [[Little Rock, Arkansas]], with the satellite feeds used to deliver the complete signals to the individual station transmitter sites and to [[cable television]] operators. The future status of these stations is unknown, as [[Equity Media Holdings]] filed for [[chapter 11]] [[bankruptcy]] on December 8, 2008. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{satbeams footprint|5732|Galaxy-18 C-band North America Beam}} *{{satbeams footprint|5733|Galaxy-18 Ku-band North America Beam}} {{Intelsat |state=collapsed}} {{Orbital launches in 2008}} [[Category:Communications satellites in geostationary orbit]] [[Category:Satellite television]] [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 2008]] [[Category:Spacecraft launched by Zenit and Energia rockets]] [[Category:Satellites using the SSL 1300 bus]]

{{unreferenced|date=September 2009}} {{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|Switzerland}} "Guardando il sole" | image = | caption = | year = 1968 | country = Switzerland | artist = Gianni Mascolo | as = | with = | language = Italian | languages = | composer = Aldo D'Addario | lyricist = Sanzio Chiesa | conductor = Mario Robbiani | place = 13th | points = 2 | place_semi = | points_semi = | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1968ch from Diggiloo Thrush] | clip = | prev = Quel cœur vas-tu briser? | prev_link = Quel cœur vas-tu briser? | next = Bonjour, Bonjour | next_link = Bonjour, Bonjour }} '''"Guardando il sole"''' ([[English language|English]] translation: "Looking into the sun") was the [[Switzerland|Swiss]] entry in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1968]], performed in [[Italian language|Italian]] by [[Gianni Mascolo]].
In the song Mascolo says that prays he would like to stay to looking into the sun, prays to see the rainbow. He says that he would like to see his lover and says "I love you" Finally he would like to hold the hand's lover in his hands even he wasn't a star of his lover.
The song was performed sixth on the night (following [[Luxembourg]]'s [[Chris Bardo]] & [[Sophie Garel]] "[[Nous vivrons d'amour]]" and preceding [[Monaco]]'s [[Line & Willy]] with "[[À chacun sa chanson]]"). At the close of voting, it had received 2 points, placing 13th in a field of 17.
It was succeeded as Swiss representative at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1969|1969 Contest]] by [[Paola Del Medico]] with "[[Bonjour, Bonjour]]".
{{Eurovision Song Contest 1968}} {{Switzerland in the Eurovision Song Contest}}

{{switzerland-stub}}

{{short description|Hotel with 40m deep underwater diving pool }} {{Infobox building | name = Hotel Terme Millepini | native_name = | native_name_lang = | alternate_names = | image = Hotel Terme Millepini logo.png | image_alt = | image_size = 150px | caption = Hotel logo | building_type = Hotel | owner = | location = [[Montegrotto Terme]], [[Padua]], [[Italy]] | address = Via Cataio 42, Montegrotto Terme, Italy 35036 | coordinates = {{coord|45.318966|11.784396|display=inline}} | opened_date = 1997 | renovation_date = 2013 | architect = | awards = [[Guinness World Records]] for Deepest Swimming Pool for Diving | designations = | ren_architect = Emanuele Boaretto | ren_awards = | rooms = 100 | url = http://www.millepini.it/ | embedded = | references = }} '''Hotel Terme Millepini''' is a four-star hotel in [[Montegrotto Terme]], [[Padua]], [[Italy]]. It contains 100 rooms and is recognized for having the world's deepest pool, the Y-40, which put it in the [[Guinness World Records]].<ref name=Tele1>{{cite web|author1=Olivia Rzadkiewicz|title=Dive into the world's deepest swimming pool at 130ft|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/activityandadventure/11113946/Dive-into-the-worlds-deepest-swimming-pool-at-130ft.html|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=24 September 2014|date=22 September 2014}}</ref> The hotel was first built in 1997 and renovated in 2013.<ref name=IncMag /><ref>{{cite web|title=Y-40: we are officially a Guinnes World records!|url=http://www.millepini.it/en/immersioni/y-40-guinnes-world-record-pool.htm|publisher=Millepini|accessdate=24 September 2014}}</ref>
==Y-40 pool== [[File:Y-40 Deep Joy Logo.jpg|left|thumb|upright|The pool's logo]] Y-40 "The Deep Joy" pool first opened on 5 June 2014 and was designed by architect Emanuele Boaretto. It is {{convert|42.15|m|ft|0}} deep, making it the deepest pool in the world. It contains {{convert|4300|m3|usgal|-3}} of thermal water kept at a temperature of {{convert|32|-|34|C|F|0}}.<ref name=independent>{{cite web|author1=Chloe Hamilton|title=Y-40 Deep Joy: This is the world's deepest swimming pool|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/travel/y40-deep-joy-the-worlds-deepest-swimming-pool-9751484.html|work=[[The Independent]]|accessdate=24 September 2014|date=23 September 2014}}</ref> The pool features underwater caves and a suspended, transparent, underwater tunnel for guests to walk through. It includes platforms at various depths, ranging from {{convert|1.3|m|ft}} to {{convert|12|m|ft}}, before the walls of the pool narrow into a well-like funnel which plunges straight down to {{convert|40|m|ft|0}}. The hotel offers tickets to [[freedive]] and [[scuba dive]].<ref name=Tele1 /><ref>{{cite web|title=Y-40 The Deep Joy|url=http://www.y-40.com/en/content/8-discover-y-40|publisher=Y-40|accessdate=24 September 2014}}</ref> Italian freediver [[Umberto Pelizzari]] first measured the depth before the pool was open.<ref name=independent />
When it opened on 5 June 2014, it was awarded the "Deepest Swimming Pool for Diving" by the [[Guinness World Records]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Deepest swimming pool for diving|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/11000/deepest-swimming-pool-for-diving|publisher=Guinness World Records|accessdate=24 September 2014}}</ref> That record was previously held by the [[Nemo 33]] pool in Belgium.
==Gallery== <gallery> File:Y-40 Hotel Terme Millepini.jpg|View of the funnel that goes down 40 m File:Y-40 Tunnel Hotel Terme Millepini.jpg|View from the tunnel that guests can walk through in the pool </gallery>
==External links== *[http://www.millepini.it/ Hotel website] *[http://www.y-40.com Pool website]
==References== {{reflist|refs= <ref name=IncMag>{{cite web|title=Hotel Terme Millepini-Montegrotto Terme|url=http://www.incentivemag.com/Meeting-Facilities/Montegrotto-Terme-Italy/Convention-Hotel/Hotel-Terme-Millepini-Montegrotto-Terme-p5929262|work=Incentive Magazine|publisher=Northstar Travel Media LLC|accessdate=24 September 2014}}</ref> }}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Terme Millepini}} [[Category:Hotels in Italy]] [[Category:Hotels established in 1977]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Padua|Hotel Terme Millepini]] [[Category:Underwater diving sites]] [[Category:Swimming venues in Italy]] [[Category:World record holders]]

{{Infobox Radio Show | show_name = Howard 100 News | image = howard100newslogo-cropped_93617.jpg | imagesize = 250px | format = News | previous runtime = Noon update: 5 minutes
Hourly update: 5 minutes
A Week in Review: 1 hour | creator = [[Howard Stern]] | formerly starred = [[Mike Hambrick]]
[[Lisa Glasberg|Lisa G.]]
[[Shuli Egar]]
[[Jon Leiberman]]
Michael Morales
Brad Driver | country = [[United States]] | first_aired = October 19, 2005 | last_aired = February, 2015 | website = [http://www.sirius.com/howardstern www.sirius.com/howardstern] | home_station = [[Howard 100 and Howard 101]] }} '''Howard 100 News''' was a [[News broadcasting#Radio news|radio news]] team established by American radio personality [[Howard Stern]]. The group was formed in October 2005 following Stern's announced move from regular radio to [[Sirius Satellite Radio]] in 2006. From January 2006 until February 2015, Howard 100 News would broadcast an hourly summary of stories related to Stern, his [[The Howard Stern Show|radio show]], and those associated with it, on [[Howard 100 and Howard 101]]. The team was downsized in 2006 and again in February 2015, with only a few staffers remaining to follow the lives of the unusual Stern fans and callers known as "The Wack Pack." ==Background== On October 6, 2004, Stern announced the signing of a five-year contract with [[Sirius Satellite Radio]] starting from January 2006.{{cite web |url= http://www.howardstern.com/rundown.hs?j=p&d=1097121600 |title= Howard To Sirius Satellite In '06 - Predicts End Of Broadcast Radio! |publisher= howardstern.com |first= Jason |last= Kaplan |date= October 6, 2004 |accessdate= August 20, 2010}} The move followed a crackdown on perceived indecency in broadcasting that occurred following the [[Super Bowl XXXVIII halftime show controversy|controversy]] surrounding the [[Super Bowl XXXVIII]] halftime show in February. The incident prompted tighter control over content by station owners and managers, leading to Stern feeling "dead inside" creatively.{{cite news | first = Howard | last = Kurtz | title = Stern On Satellite: A Bruised Flower, Blossoming Anew | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/12/10/AR2005121001432.html | work = The Washington Post | date= December 11, 2005 | accessdate = September 18, 2009 }} The five-year deal allowed Stern to produce up to three channels on Sirius with a $100 million per year budget for all production, staff and programming costs including the construction of a dedicated studio.{{cite web | url = http://www.secinfo.com/dsvRa.13ej.htm | title = Sirius Satellite Radio Inc. 8-K For 10/1/04 | publisher = SEC Info | date = October 1, 2004 | accessdate = March 25, 2010 }} ==Launch and original team== [[Howard 100 and Howard 101]] went live for the first time on September 29, 2005, initially broadcasting silence.{{cite news | title = Sounds Of Silence As Howard Stern Channel Launches On Sirius | url = http://www.fmqb.com/article.asp?id=122230 | work = FMQB | date = September 29, 2005 | accessdate = January 10, 2011 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120204100526/http://www.fmqb.com/Article.asp?id=122230 | archivedate = February 4, 2012 | df = }} As Stern was still under contract with [[Infinity Broadcasting]] until January 1, 2006, he could not broadcast any material from the two channels, or talk on its airwaves. Howard 100 News was created by Talk Radio Consultant Walter Sabo, then in-house at Sirius, who worked with Stern on the concept, and CBS News Anchor Jessica Ettinger Gottesman, then an anchor at CBS-owned 1010 WINS-AM all-news radio. Howard 100 News was crafted to sound like 1010 WINS, and aired its first newscast on October 19, 2005, after off-air trial runs. Original content included radio personality [[Bubba the Love Sponge]] interviewing Stern's former writer [[Jackie Martling]].{{cite news | title = Howard Stern Channel Debuts "Howard 100 News" | url = http://www.fmqb.com/article.asp?id=135949 | work = FMQB | date = October 19, 2005 | accessdate = January 10, 2011 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101006070647/http://www.fmqb.com/Article.asp?id=135949 | archivedate = October 6, 2010 | df = }} The team eventually grew to 17 staffers, many of whom were professional journalists,{{cite web |url= http://www.howardstern.com/rundown.hs?j=n&d=1129694400 |title= Isn't He Wonderful |publisher= HowardStern.com |first= Jason |last= Kaplan |date= October 20, 2005 |accessdate= January 10, 2011}} including [[Jessica Ettinger]], who, while still employed at CBS, used the on-air name Erica Phillips, as well as [[Lisa Glasberg]] (known as Lisa G.), and Steve Langford. Just days after being fired from [[WNYW-TV]], the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox TV]] station in New York, reporter [[Penny Crone]] was hired to work for Howard 100 News.{{cite news|first=Richard |last=Huff |title=Stern's news is Pennywise |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/entertainment/2006/01/06/2006-01-06_stern_s_news_is_pennywise.html |work=New York Daily News |date=January 6, 2006 |accessdate=January 10, 2011 }}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Crone has since left broadcasting and now works as a licensed real estate agent.[https://www.elliman.com/real-estate-agent/penny-crone/673 Penny Crone profile on DouglasElliman Real Estate website] ==The team now== In June 2006, most of the Howard 100 News staffers were let go. Stern said that this was because it needed downsizing. News director Liz Aiello departed to become the vice president and general manager of [[Martha Stewart Living Radio]] on Sirius XM. {{cite news| url=http://www.nydailynews.com/08-04-2006/entertainment/ent_radio/story/440436p-371030c.html | location=New York | work=Daily News | title=New York News, Traffic, Sports, Weather, Photos, Entertainment, and Gossip - NY Daily News }} {{Dead link|date=January 2012|bot=RjwilmsiBot}} Erica Phillips, who also worked at [[CBS News]] under her real name, became news director before assuming program director duties at other Sirius channels. Reporters Penny Crone and George Flowers left the team in January 2007 due to budget cuts.{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/story/489252p-412048c.html |location=New York |work=Daily News |title=New York Arts - NYC Entertainment News - NY Daily News |date=April 1, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070125161259/http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/story/489252p-412048c.html |archivedate=January 25, 2007 }} Most of the other staffers were released in February 2015, leaving [[Shuli Egar]] and [[Jon Leiberman]], who had developed expertise covering Stern's unusual fans and callers, known as "The Wack Pack." They are continuing those assignments, under News Director Brad Driver. The news team is no longer referred to as Howard 100 News. ==The team== [[File:Howard 100 News Team, Winter 2005-2006.jpg|thumb|right|Most of the original Howard 100 News crew.]] ===Current=== *[[Shuli Egar]] *[[Jon Leiberman]] *Brad Driver (news director since December 2006) ===Former=== *Mike Hambrick *Michael "High Pitch Mike" Morales *[[Lisa Glasberg]] (Lisa G.) (Nov 05 - Feb 15) *Liz Aiello (Dec 05 - Aug 06) *[[Jessica_Ettinger|Erica Phillips]] (Sept 05 - Nov 06) *Mike Piazza (Oct 05 - Jun 06) *Phil Iazzetta (Oct 05 - Jun 06) *Michelle Jerson (Oct 05 - Jun 06) *[[Penny Crone]] (Jan 06 - Jan 07) *George Flowers (Sept 05 - Jan 07) *Ralph Howard (Oct 05 - May 13) *Steve Juchnevcius *James Kouledianos *Lou Pelligrino *Lisa Zerbo *Steve Langford (Oct 05 - Jul 11) ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20091209090740/http://www.howardstern.com/archive.hs?h=493 Today on the Howard 100 News] *[http://www.howard100channelguide.com/ Howard 100 Channel Guide] *[http://www.howardstern.com/ Howard Stern’s Official Website] *[http://www.sirius.com/ Sirius Website] *[http://www.sternfannetwork.com/ Stern Fan Network] {{Howard_Stern_Show}} [[Category:Sirius Satellite Radio]] [[Category:2005 establishments in North America]] [[Category:Howard Stern]]

revision.text:
{{about|a historical administrative term in Ukraine|its usage in Poland|Gromada|its usage in Belarus|Hramada|other uses}} {{wiktionary}}
'''''Hromada''''' ({{lang-uk|[[:uk:громада|Громада]]}}) is a Ukrainian term for [[community]] or public, more precise an association of the people united by mutual interest, position or goal, widely known in [[Ukraine]]. Similar terms could be found in [[Poland]] and [[Belarus]].
In history of [[Ukraine]] and [[Belarus]] such associations appeared first as [[peasant]] communes, which gathered their meetings for discussing and resolving current issues. In the 19th century there were number of political organization with the same name.
Hromada means not only social association of some people, but in broader sense a symbolic unity of any territorial population or the whole national society.
Name "hromada" was frequently used by political and social organizations, [[newspaper]]s in [[Ukraine]].
At present, the term is more often applied in Ukraine, as a "territorial commune" ({{lang-uk|[[:uk:Територіальна громада|Територіальна громада]]}}) naming the population of any region. The [[Constitution of Ukraine]] and some other laws, including the "Law on local self-governance", delegate certain rights and obligations for "hromada". But "hromada" does not have the rights of a [[Legal person|legal entity]]. In his draft [[Ukraine's constitution|constitutional]] amendments of June 2014 [[Ukrainian President]] [[Petro Poroshenko]] proposed changing the [[administrative divisions of Ukraine]], which should include regions, districts and "hromadas".<ref>[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/211043.html Poroshenko suggests granting status of regions to Crimea, Kyiv, Sevastopol, creating new political subdivision of 'community'] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140701043549/http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/211043.html |date=2014-07-01 }}, [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (26 June 2014)</ref>
==Other uses== [[File:Hromada (Geneva) vol 5 no 1.jpg|thumb|Swiss magazine "Hromada"|100px]] In the [[History of Ukraine]] the word was used to denote [[medieval commune]]s in Ukraine. There also were several political entities such as [[Hromada (political party)]] (modern Ukraine) and [[Hromada (secret society)]] (in [[Russian Empire]]).
[[Mykhailo Drahomanov]] in his exile was publishing Hromada magazine in [[Switzerland]].
==See also== * [[Gromada (disambiguation)]] * [[Hramada]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Ukrainian society]]
{{Ukraine-stub}}

page.title: Kenyan migration to the United Kingdom

revision.text:
{{Infobox ethnic group | group = Kenyan Britons | image = |population='''Kenyan-born residents'''
129,633 (2001 Census)
203,000 (2009 ONS estimate)
137,492 in England and Wales (2011 census) |popplace= [[London]], [[South East England]], [[East Midlands]] |langs= English ([[British English|British]], [[Kenyan English|Kenyan]]), [[Languages of India|Indian Languages]] |rels= [[Christianity]], [[Sikhism]], [[Islam]], [[Hinduism]] |related= }} '''Kenyan migration to the United Kingdom''' has been occurring for many decades. As a result, many people in the [[United Kingdom|UK]] were born in [[Kenya]], or have Kenyan ancestry. Many Kenyan people who migrated to the UK are of South Asian extraction. ==Background== {{unreferenced section|date=October 2010}} Most Kenyans in the UK are ethnically [[South Asia]]n Kenyans who, like those in Uganda, were forced out during the late 1960s and early 1970s.http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/shared/spl/hi/uk/05/born_abroad/countries/html/kenya.stm This community has a substantial cluster in Leicester and London.http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/shared/spl/hi/uk/05/born_abroad/countries/html/kenya.stm The most recent growth may now be coming from ethnically [[black people|black]] African Kenyans, mirroring wider trends across the continent of economic migration to the richer industrialised nations.http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/shared/spl/hi/uk/05/born_abroad/countries/html/kenya.stm There are also a small number of Kenyan-born people who are the children of British civil servants based there before the end of the Empire.http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/shared/spl/hi/uk/05/born_abroad/countries/html/kenya.stm ==Demographics== The [[2001 UK Census]] recorded 129,633 Kenyan-born British residents.{{cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/dataoecd/18/23/34792376.xls |title=Country-of-birth database |publisher=[[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]] |accessdate=16 October 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090617032129/http://www.oecd.org/dataoecd/18/23/34792376.xls |archivedate=17 June 2009 |df= }} The equivalent figure in 2009 has been estimated at 203,000 by the [[Office for National Statistics]].{{cite web |url=http://www.statistics.gov.uk/downloads/theme_population/Population-by-country-of-birth-and-nationality-Oct08-Sep09.zip |title=Estimated population resident in the United Kingdom, by foreign country of birth (Table 1.3) |publisher=[[Office for National Statistics]] |date=September 2009 |accessdate=16 October 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5vvnKhoUi?url=http://www.statistics.gov.uk/downloads/theme_population/Population-by-country-of-birth-and-nationality-Oct08-Sep09.zip |archivedate=22 January 2011 |df= }} Figure given is the central estimate. See the source for 95 per cent [[confidence interval]]s. The largest proportion of Kenyan-born British residents are found in the capital, [[London]], where around half of the Kenyan-born population in Britain resides. There are also significant populations in the [[South East England|South East]] and the [[East Midlands]].{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/shared/spl/hi/uk/05/born_abroad/countries/html/kenya.stm|title=Kenya|work=Born Abroad|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=16 October 2010}} ==Famous Britons born in Kenya== ===Academia, Medicine and Science=== * [[Richard Dawkins]], ethologist, biologist, writer * [[Azim Nanji]], academic * [[Alan Rayner]], biologist * [[Nilesh Samani|Sir Nilesh Samani]], physician * [[Tejinder Virdee|Sir Tejinder Virdee]], physicist ===Business, Law and Politics=== * [[Michael Bear (Lord Mayor)|Michael Bear]], Lord Mayor of London * [[Peter Hain]], Political campaigner and former cabinet minister * [[Usha Prashar, Baroness Prashar|Baroness Prashar]], businesswoman * [[Mohamed Sheikh, Baron Sheikh|Lord Sheikh]], businessman, Conservative politician ===Music and the Arts=== * [[Khadambi Asalache]], poet * [[Kamara Bacchus]], actress * [[Kuljit Bhamra]], musician * [[Gurinder Chadha]], film director * [[Nitin Ganatra]], actor * [[Kulvinder Ghir]], comedian * [[Tania Harcourt-Cooze]], model and actress * [[Elspeth Huxley]], author, journalist, broadcaster * [[Viram Jasani]], musician * [[Michael Kuhn]], film producer * [[Charles Mnene]], actor * [[Deep Roy]], actor, stuntman * [[Roger Whittaker]], musician * [[Imran Yusuf]], comedian * [[Adrian Zagoritis]], music producer and songwriter ===Sport=== * [[Roger Chapman (golfer)|Roger Chapman]], golfer * [[Jamie Dalrymple]], cricketer * [[Chris Froome]], racing cyclist * [[Rajesh Maru]], cricketer * [[Derek Pringle]], cricketer * [[Peter Thackeray]], cricketer * [[Curtis Osano]], footballer * [[Victor Wanyama]], footballer * [[Simon Shaw]], rugby union player * [[Anne Wafula Strike]], Wheelchair racing ==See also== *[[Black British]] *[[British Mixed]] *[[British African-Caribbean community]] == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== {{AfricansinUK}} {{Kenyan diaspora}} [[Category:Black British people|*Kenyan]] [[Category:Immigration to the United Kingdom by country of origin]] [[Category:Kenyan emigrants to the United Kingdom| ]] {{UK-stub}} {{ethno-group-stub}}

(Koula Moutou Airport) | nativename = | image = | IATA = KOU | ICAO = FOGK | pushpin_map = Gabon | pushpin_map_caption = Location of Koulamoutou Airport in Gabon | pushpin_label = KOU | pushpin_label_position = bottom | type = Public | owner = | operator = | city-served = | location = [[Koulamoutou]], [[Gabon]] | elevation-f = 1,070 | elevation-m = 326 | coordinates = {{coord|01|11|04|S|012|26|28|E|region:GA_type:airport}} | website = | metric-rwy = y | r1-number = 15/33 | r1-length-m = 1,780 | r1-length-f = 5,841 | r1-surface = Asphalt | footnotes = Source: [[DAFIF]][http://www.worldaerodata.com/wad.cgi?airport=FOGK Airport information for FOGK] from [[DAFIF]] (effective October 2006) GCM{{GCM|KOU|source=DAFIF}} Google Maps[https://www.google.com/maps/@-1.1889029,12.4402032,7073m/data=!3m1!1e3 Google Maps - Koulamoutou] }} '''Koulamoutou Airport''' or '''Koula Moutou Airport''' {{airport codes|KOU|FOGK}} is an [[airport]] serving [[Koulamoutou]], the [[capital city|capital]] of the [[Ogooué-Lolo Province]] in central [[Gabon]]. The Koulamoutou [[non-directional beacon]] (Ident:'''KL''') is located just north of the runway.{{Cite web|url=https://skyvector.com/?ll=-1.17,12.431085&chart=301&zoom=1|title=SkyVector: Flight Planning / Aeronautical Charts|website=skyvector.com|access-date=2018-08-20}} ==Facilities== The airport resides at an [[elevation]] of {{convert|1070|ft|0}} above [[mean sea level]]. It has one [[runway]] designated 15/33 with an [[asphalt]] surface measuring {{convert|1780|x|45|m|0}}. ==See also== *{{Portal-inline|Gabon}} *{{portal-inline|Aviation}} * [[List of airports in Gabon]] * [[Transport in Gabon]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.openstreetmap.org/#map=13/-1.1831/12.4421 OpenStreetMap - Koulamoutou] *[http://ourairports.com/airports/FOGK/pilot-info.html#general OurAirports - Koulamoutou] [[Category:Airports in Gabon]] [[Category:Ogooué-Lolo Province]] {{Gabon-airport-stub}}

{{Use American English|date=May 2017}} {{coord|0|-47.5|display=title}} {{Infobox spaceflight | name = NSS-806 | image = | image_caption = | mission_type = [[Communications satellite|Communications]] | operator = [[Intelsat]] → [[SES World Skies]] | website = | COSPAR_ID = [http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=1998-014A 1998-014A] | SATCAT = 25239 | mission_duration = 15 years | spacecraft_bus = | spacecraft_type = [[Spacebus|AS-7000]] | manufacturer = [[Lockheed Martin]] | dry_mass = {{convert|2,200|kg|lb|abbr=on}}{{cite web|url=http://www.satbeams.com/satellites?norad=25239|title=NSS-806|work=SatBeams - Satellite Details|accessdate=May 7, 2017}} | BOL_mass = | launch_mass = {{convert|3,720|kg|lb|abbr=on}} | dimensions = | power = | launch_date = {{start-date|February 28, 1998, 00:21|timezone=yes}} UTC{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/launchlog.txt|title=Launch Log|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|work=Jonathan's Space Page|accessdate=May 7, 2017}} | launch_rocket = [[Atlas II]]AS AC-151 | launch_site = [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]] [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 36|SLC-36B]] | launch_contractor = | disposal_type = | deactivated = | orbit_epoch = May 7, 2017{{cite web|url=http://www.n2yo.com/satellite/?s=25239|title=INTELSAT 806 |work=N2YO|accessdate=May 7, 2017}} | orbit_reference = [[geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[geostationary orbit|Geostationary]] | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|35,767.0|km|mi}}{{cite web|url=http://heavens-above.com/orbit.aspx?satid=25239&lat=-43.533&lng=172.633&loc=Christchurch&alt=7&tz=NZST |title=NSS 806 (INTELSAT 806) |first=Chris |last=Peat |work=Heavens Above |accessdate=May 7, 2017}} | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|35,806.0|km|mi}} | orbit_inclination = 0.058° | orbit_period = 1,436.1 minutes | orbit_eccentricity = 0.0004615 | apsis = gee | trans_band = 28 [[C band (IEEE)|C Band]], 3 {{Ku band}} | trans_frequency = | trans_bandwidth = | trans_capacity = | trans_coverage = [[Americas]], [[Europe]] | trans_TWTA = | trans_EIRP = | trans_HPBW = | programme = ''Intelsat 8'' | previous_mission = [[Intelsat 805]] | next_mission = [[Intelsat 901]] (Intelsat 9) }} '''NSS-806''' ('''New Skies Satellite 806'''), before '''Intelsat 806''', is a [[communications satellite]] originally operated by [[Intelsat]]. Launched in 1998 it was operated in [[geostationary orbit]] at a longitude of 47 degrees west for around 15 years. It is currently located in the orbital position of 47.5 degrees west longitude, was initially operated by [[Intelsat]], orbited at 40.5 degrees west, and was purchased by [[SES World Skies]] (a subsidiary of [[SES S.A.|SES]]). == Satellite == NSS-806 is equipped with 28 [[transponder]]s in [[C band (IEEE)|C band]] and 3 in [[Ku band]], making transmissions for the [[Americas]] and parts of [[Europe]]. In order to receive the signal it requires a monofocal antenna (LNBF antenna in the center), a [[LNBF]] for C band (5150 [[Hertz (unit)|MHz]]) and a digital receiver compatible with C band. The NSS-806 emits its signal in circular polarization. == Launch == The launch of NSS-806 made use of a [[Atlas II]] rocket flying from [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station]], [[Florida]], [[United States]]. The launch took place at 00:16 UTC on February 28, 1998, with the spacecraft entering a [[geosynchronous transfer orbit]]. NSS-806 subsequently fired its apogee motor to achieve [[geostationary orbit]]. == Health and replacement == In July 2017, seven years past its 12 year intended design life, NSS-806 lost the use of 12 of its 39 transponders. NSS-806's replacement, [[SES-14]], was scheduled to be launched in first quarter of 2018 on a [[SpaceX]] [[Falcon 9]], and SES predicted that the transponder failure would result in a revenue loss of between 7 and 9 million euros.{{cite web|url=http://spacenews.com/ses-loses-12-transponders-on-nss-806-satellite-says-impact-is-temporary/ |title=SES loses 12 transponders on NSS-806 satellite, says impact is temporary |first=Caleb |last=Henry |work=Space News |date=July 31, 2017 |accessdate=January 27, 2018}} The following month, SES arranged to swap flights so that SES-12 would launch in January 2018 on an [[Ariane 5]], with [[SES-12]], originally scheduled for that flight, now launching on the Falcon 9 later in Q1.{{cite web|url=http://spacenews.com/ses-flips-spacex-arianespace-launches-to-speed-nss-806-replacement/ |title=SES flips SpaceX, Arianespace launches to speed NSS-806 replacement |first=Caleb |last=Henry |work=Space News |date=August 28, 2017 |accessdate=January 27, 2018}} SES-14 was launched from [[Guiana Space Centre|Kourou]] on 25 January, 2018, but was placed in an incorrect orbit due to a launch vehicle anomaly. SES reported that the all-electric SES-14 would take four more weeks than originally planned to reach its operating orbit, but that the satellite was healthy and was expected to meet its designed life time. SES-14's in-service date, originally set for July 2018, was expected to be pushed back until at least August 2018.{{cite web|url=http://spacenews.com/satellites-placed-into-incorrect-orbits-by-ariane-5-can-be-recovered-owners-say/ |title=Satellites placed into incorrect orbits by Ariane 5 can be recovered, owners say |first=Caleb |last=Henry |work=Space News |date=January 26, 2018 |accessdate=January 27, 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.ses.com/press-release/ses-14-good-health-and-track-despite-launch-anomaly |title=SES-14 in good health and on track despite launch anomaly |first=Markus |last=Payer |work=SES |date=January 26, 2018 |accessdate=January 27, 2018}} ==Technical details== {| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto;" ! colspan="4" | C-Band slot chart |- !Slot !Uplink ([[Gigahertz|Ghz]]) !Downlink (Ghz) !Hemi A !Hemi B ![[Bandwidth (computing)|Bandwidth]] ([[Megahertz|Mhz]]) |- | 5'-6' | 6.527 | 3.502 | 12' | 22' | 72 |- | 3'-4' | 6.607 | 3.582 | 11' | 21' | 72 |- | 1'-2' | 5.888 | 3.663 | 10 | 20 | 72 |- | 1-2 | 5.968 | 3.743 | 11 | 21 | 72 |- | 3 | 6.028 | 3.803 | 12A | 22A | 36 |- | 4 | 6.068 | 3.843 | 12B | 22B | 36 |- | 5 | 6.108 | 3.883 | 13A | 23A | 36 |- | 6 | 6.148 | 3.923 | 13B | 23B | 36 |- | 7 | 6.201 | 3.976 | 14A | 24A | 36 |- | 9 | 6.280 | 4.055 | 15 | 25 | 36 |- | 10 | 6.320 | 4.095 | 16 | 26 | 36 |- | 11 | 6.360 | 4.135 | 17 | 27 | 36 |- | 12 | 6.4025 | 4.1775 | 18 | 28 | 41 |- |} {| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto;" ! colspan="4" | Ku-band slot chart |- !Slot !Uplink ([[Gigahertz|Ghz]])
{{small|Polariztion H}} !Downlink (Ghz)
{{small|Polarization V}} !Spot 1 ![[Bandwidth (computing)|Bandwidth]] ([[Megahertz|Mhz]]) |- | 1-2 | 14.0425 | 12.7475 | 261 | 77 |- | 3-4 | 14.125 | 11.830 | 262 | 72 |- | 5-6 | 14.205 | 11.910 | 263 | 72 |- |} {{Portal|Spaceflight}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{Intelsat}} {{SES satellites}} {{Orbital launches in 1998}} [[Category:Intelsat satellites]] [[Category:SES satellites]] [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 1998]] [[Category:Communications satellites in geostationary orbit]] {{Netherlands-spacecraft-stub}} {{US-spacecraft-stub}}

{{URL|www.oasisglobal.org}} | remarks = | formerly = | footnotes = {{EW charity |num=1026487 |name=Oasis Charitable Trust}} }} '''Oasis Charitable Trust''' (known as '''Oasis''') is a UK-based [[Christian]] [[registered charity]]. It was founded by the Reverend [[Steve Chalke]] in September 1985. Chalke had been assistant minister at [[Tonbridge]] Baptist Church, [[Kent]], for four years. He left this job with the aim of setting up a hostel for homeless young people. Oasis now has over 5,000 staff in the UK as well as thousands more volunteers. Since its foundation Oasis has also developed into a family of charities now working on four continents (11 countries) around the world, with the goal of delivering housing, education, training, youthwork and healthcare. Oasis is now a significant [[voluntary sector]] provider, delivering services for local authorities and national governments, as well as self funded initiatives.{{cite web|url=http://www.oasisglobal.org/|title=Home - Oasis Global Site|website=www.oasisglobal.org}} Oasis currently works in 51 local neighbourhoods – 35 of which are in the UK – where it seeks to bring together the resources, expertise and infrastructure that it has developed over the years, in order to build on existing strengths and assets in the local community. Oasis' aim is always to serve and respect all people regardless of their gender, race, ethnic origin, religion, age, sexual orientation or physical and mental capability and to work with the whole community to create a neighbourhood in which people feel known, are able to thrive, achieve their God-given potential and build deep and nourishing relationships. ==Oasis Church Waterloo== In 2003, under [[Steve Chalke]]'s leadership, Oasis, having become responsible for the buildings of Christ Church and Upton Chapel, in [[Lambeth|Waterloo]], central [[London]], worked with the existing members there to form what was initially known as Church.co.uk. Since then it has been renamed as Oasis Church, Waterloo. Christ Church and Upton Chapel actually began its life as Surrey Chapel in 1783, and was to provide a major influence in the start of the Ragged School Movement – which provided schools for local children from poor homes – and also supported the birth of the Shaftesbury Society, the YMCA and the Bible Society. In the 1800s it was also influential in the anti-slavery movement; William Wilberforce and friends made its building a venue for many of their anti-slavery meetings, and its spire, built in 1867, is named the Lincoln Tower, donated in memory of Abraham Lincoln who was both inspired and supported by in his work to achieve the emancipation of the slaves of North America through the network of friends based in London. That same commitment to serve Christ through ‘loving God’ and ‘loving our neighbours as ourselves’ continues to underpin the work of the present day church. Over the years since 2003 a wide range of community services focussed on the half-mile radius around the building, have been developed including a children’s centre, a primary school, a secondary school, various adult education opportunities, a foodbank, a debt advice centre, a community farm, a coffee shop, as well as becoming responsible for the local public library and launching various other youth projects and programmes.http://www.oasiswaterloo.org/ Further Oasis churches have developed running alongside the communities of the Oasis Academies in [[Salford, Greater Manchester|Salford]], [[Oldham]], [[Oasis Academy Brightstowe|Brightstowe]], [[Bristol]], [[London Borough of Enfield|Enfield]], Southampton ([[Lord's Hill]] & [[Mayfield Park, Southampton|Mayfield]]), [[Immingham]] and [[Wintringham]].http://www.oasischurch.info/church_default.aspx The Oasis church network has five values which are at the heart of their work; inclusion, interdependence, intimacy, involvement and influence.{{cite web|url=http://www.oasiswaterloo.org/vision-goals-and-values|title=Vision, goals and values - Oasis Waterloo Hub|website=www.oasiswaterloo.org}} ==Stop The Traffik== Stop The Traffik is one of the Oasis subsidiary charities. It is a global coalition working in nearly 100 countries and in partnership with multiple other charitable organisations, businesses and anti-trafficking agencies with the goal of disrupting and preventing human trafficking.{{cite web|url=http://www.stopthetraffik.org/uk/|title=STOP THE TRAFFIK - People shouldn't be bought and sold|website=STOP THE TRAFFIK}} ==Oasis Aquila Housing== Oasis Aquila Housing delivers bespoke and effective services for vulnerably housed and homeless people, in the North East as well as in South London. Annually it supports over 1000 people with housing needs.http://www.oasisaquilahousing.org/ ==The Oasis Foundation== The newest part of the Oasis family, is dedicated to demonstrating the effectiveness of Oasis' model of community engagement and to encouraging and facilitating its replication. The Foundation focuses on commissioning and disseminating research, on informing and influencing social policy but, most importantly, on promoting and supporting the role of local churches in public service delivery as an integrated part of their purpose.{{cite web|url=https://oasis.foundation/|title=Oasis Foundation|website=oasis.foundation}} ==Oasis Community Learning== Oasis Community Learning{{EW charity|1109288|Oasis Community Learning}} is one of OAsis Trust's subsidiary charities. It is an umbrella group to govern the Oasis Academies which are schools classed as [[Academy (England)|academies]]. The first three Oasis academies in [[Enfield Lock]], [[Grimsby]] and [[Immingham]], opened in September 2007, with six more, two in [[Bristol]], two in [[Southampton]], two in [[Oasis Academy Coulsdon|Croydon]] and one in [[City of Salford|Salford]], opening in September 2008. Since then, OAsis has grown to be one of the country's largest Multi-Academy Trusts (MATs) and is currently responsible for 47 schools around England; a mix of primary, secondary and all-through academies.http://www.oasiscommunitylearning.org/academies/ ===Oasis Academies=== ====Primary==== {{Div col|colwidth=30em}} *Oasis Academy Aspinal, Gorton *Oasis Academy Bank Leaze, Bristol *Oasis Academy Blakenhale Infants, Garretts Green, Birmingham *Oasis Academy Blakenhale Junior, Garretts Green, Birmingham *Oasis Academy Boulton, Birmingham *Oasis Academy Byron, Coulsdon, London *Oasis Academy Connaught, Knowle, Bristol *Oasis Academy Firvale, Sheffield *Oasis Academy Foundry, Soho, Birmingham *Oasis Academy Harpur Mount, Harpurhey, Manchester *Oasis Academy Henderson Avenue, Scunthorpe *Oasis Academy Hobmoor, Yardley, Birmingham *Oasis Academy Johanna, Lower Marsh, London *Oasis Academy Limeside, Oldham *Oasis Academy Long Cross, Bristol *Oasis Academy Marksbury Road, Bristol *Oasis Academy New Oak, Bristol *Oasis Academy Nunsthorpe, Grimsby *Oasis Academy Parkwood, Scunthorpe *Oasis Academy Pinewood, Collier Row, London *Oasis Academy Putney, London *Oasis Academy Ryelands, South Norwood, London *Oasis Academy Short Heath, Erdington, Birmingham *Oasis Academy Skinner Street, Gillingham *Oasis Academy Warndon, Worcester *Oasis Academy Watermead, Sheffield *Oasis Academy Woodview, Edgbaston, Birmingham {{div col end}} ====Secondary==== {{Div col|colwidth=30em}} *[[Oasis Academy Arena]], South Norwood, London *[[Oasis Academy Brightstowe]], Shirehampton, Bristol *[[Oasis Academy Brislington]], Brislington, Bristol *[[Oasis Academy Coulsdon]], Old Coulsdon, London *[[Oasis Academy Enfield]], Enfield Lock, London *[[Oasis Academy Hextable]], Hextable, Kent *[[Oasis Academy Immingham]], Immingham *[[Oasis Academy Isle of Sheppey]], Isle of Sheppey, Kent *[[Oasis Academy John Williams]], Hengrove, Bristol *[[Oasis Academy Lister Park]], Bradford *[[Oasis Academy Lord's Hill]], Southampton *[[Oasis Academy Mayfield]], Southampton *[[Oasis Academy MediaCityUK]], Salford Quays, Salford *[[Oasis Academy Oldham]], Hollinwood, Oldham *[[Oasis The following [[Outline (list)|outline]] is provided as an overview of and topical guide to Liberia:
'''[[Liberia]]''' – [[List of sovereign states|country]] in [[West Africa]], bordered by [[Sierra Leone]], [[Guinea]], [[Côte d'Ivoire]], and the [[Atlantic Ocean]].<ref name=CIA_World_Factbook>{{cite web|date=July 3, 2009|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/li.html|title=Liberia|work=[[The World Factbook]]|publisher=[[United States]] [[Central Intelligence Agency]]|accessdate=July 23, 2009}}</ref> Liberia has a hot equatorial climate with most rainfall arriving in summer with harsh [[harmattan]] winds in the dry season. Liberia's populated [[Pepper Coast]] is composed of mostly [[mangrove]] forests while the sparse inland is forested, later opening to a plateau of drier grasslands. Since 1989, Liberia has been in a state of flux witnessing two [[civil war]]s, the [[First Liberian Civil War]] (1989–1996), and the [[Second Liberian Civil War]] (1999–2003), displacing hundreds of thousands of people and devastating the country's [[Economy of Liberia|economy]].
{{TOC limit|limit=2}}
== General reference == [[Image:Topographic map of Liberia-en.svg|thumb|An enlargeable map of [[Liberia]]]] * [[International Phonetic Alphabet|Pronunciation]]: {{IPAc-en|l|aɪ|ˈ|b|ɪər|i|ə}} * Common English country name: [[Liberia]] * Official English country name: The [[Republic of Liberia]] * Common [[endonym]](s): [[List of countries and capitals in native languages| ]] * Official endonym(s): [[List of official endonyms of present-day nations and states| ]] * [[List of adjectival and demonymic forms of place names#Countries and nations|Adjectival]](s): [[wikt:liberian|Liberian]] * [[List of adjectival and demonymic forms of place names#Countries and nations|Demonym]](s): * [[Etymology]]: [[Name of Liberia]] * [[ISO country codes]]: LR, LBR, 430 * [[ISO region codes]]: See [[ISO 3166-2:LR]] * [[Internet]] [[country code top-level domain]]: [[.lr]]
== Geography of Liberia == [[Image:Liberia Topography.png|thumb|An enlargeable topographic map of [[Liberia]]]]
[[Geography of Liberia]] * Liberia is: a [[Nation state|country]] * Population of Liberia: 3,750,000 - [[List of countries by population|129th most populous country]] * Area of Liberia: 111,369 km<sup>2</sup> * [[:commons:Atlas of Liberia|Atlas of Liberia]]
=== Location === * Liberia is situated within the following regions: ** [[Northern Hemisphere]] and [[Western Hemisphere]] *** [[Africa]] **** [[West Africa]] * [[Time zone]]: [[Coordinated Universal Time]] [[UTC+00]] * Extreme points of Liberia ** High: [[Mount Wuteve]] {{convert|1440|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} ** Low: [[North Atlantic Ocean]] 0 m * Land boundaries: 1,585 km ::{{Flag|Cote d'Ivoire}} 716 km ::{{Flag|Guinea}} 563 km ::{{Flag|Sierra Leone}} 306 km :* Coastline: [[North Atlantic Ocean]] 579 km
=== Environment of Liberia === [[Image:Satellite image of Liberia in January 2003.jpg|thumb|An enlargeable satellite image of [[Liberia]]]]

* Glaciers in Liberia: none <ref>The only [[List of glaciers in Africa|glaciers in Africa]] are on Mt Kenya (in Kenya), on Kilimanjaro (in Tanzania), and in the Ruwenzori Mountains (which are located in [[Uganda]] and the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]]). See [http://iahs.info/redbooks/a126/iahs_126_0197.pdf Proceedings of the Riederalp Workshop, September 1978; Actes de l'Atelier de Riederalp, septembre 1978): IAHS-AISH Publ. no. 126, 1980.]</ref> * [[List of rivers of Liberia|Rivers of Liberia]] * World Heritage Sites in Liberia: None{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}}
